items.label: Make A Draft for the TC2
Drafting Inlay for Jacquard and Harness Looms
Create Lattice Structures Using Layer Notation

howtodevelop/install.title: Install AdaCAD
howtodevelop/install.description: AdaCAD is built with Angular, a web development framework for progressive web apps. This project was generated with Angular CLI version 7.3.8.

howtodevelop/reference/cell/cell.title: Cell
howtodevelop/reference/cell/cell.description: This is a single cell or square within a drawdown. Unlike typical drafting where a cell can only be marked black, to raise a heddle at the cell's location, or white to indicate it as lowered, AdaCAD Cells can hold three values:

howtodevelop/reference/cell/createCell.title: createCell
howtodevelop/reference/cell/createCell.description: Creates a cell object with a specific value:

howtodevelop/reference/cell/getCellValue.title: getCellValue
howtodevelop/reference/cell/getCellValue.description: Returns a boolean value describing the value of this heddle as true, false, or unset.

howtodevelop/reference/cell/setCellValue.title: setCellValue
howtodevelop/reference/cell/setCellValue.description: Sets the variables of the cell object according to a boolean input.

howtodevelop/reference/draft/copyDraft.title: copyDraft
howtodevelop/reference/draft/copyDraft.description: Copies a draft to a new draft object while retaining the old draft id. Functionally, this creates a deep copy of the input draft.

howtodevelop/reference/draft/draft.title: Draft
howtodevelop/reference/draft/draft.description: In AdaCAD, a draft is a container for  a drawdown as well as information that can be used to interpret the drawdown.

howtodevelop/reference/draft/initDraft.title: initDraft
howtodevelop/reference/draft/initDraft.description: Initializes an empty draft object with a unique id with the following default values.

howtodevelop/reference/draft/initDraftFr.title: initDraftFromDrawdown
howtodevelop/reference/draft/initDraftFr.description: In many operations, you'll design the drawdown first, and then want to create a draft based on the data in that drawdown.

howtodevelop/reference/draft/initDraftWi.title: initDraftWithParams
howtodevelop/reference/draft/initDraftWi.description: Given any partial set of parameters, this function will initialize a new draft that maintains any parameters specified and fills all other values with defaults.

howtodevelop/reference/draft/updateWarpS.title: updateWarpSystemsAndShuttles
howtodevelop/reference/draft/updateWarpS.description: This function takes the colShuttleMapping and colSystemMapping from one draft, and copies it into another draft. As it does so, it trims or repeats the array to match the size of the destination draft.

howtodevelop/reference/draft/updateWeftS.title: updateWeftSystemsAndShuttles
howtodevelop/reference/draft/updateWeftS.description: This function takes the rowShuttleMapping and rowSystemMapping from one draft, and copies it into another draft. As it does so, it trims or repeats the array to match the size of the destination draft.

howtodevelop/reference/drawdown/drawdown.title: Drawdown
howtodevelop/reference/drawdown/drawdown.description: The drawdown type refers to the 2D array used to store the cells that make up the draft pattern or drawdown. The drawdown is used as the primary representation of cloth structure within a draft in AdaCAD.

howtodevelop/reference/drawdown/hasCell.title: hasCell
howtodevelop/reference/drawdown/hasCell.description: Returns true if a given index exists within a drawdown.

howtodevelop/reference/drawdown/isUp.title: isUp
howtodevelop/reference/drawdown/isUp.description: Given an index within the drawdown, it will return true or false to describe if this heddle is set and is up.

howtodevelop/reference/drawdown/setCellV.title: setCellValue
howtodevelop/reference/drawdown/setCellV.description: Sets the cell value at a given index.

howtodevelop/reference/drawdown/warps.title: warps
howtodevelop/reference/drawdown/warps.description: Gets the number of warps in a drawdown

howtodevelop/reference/drawdown/wefts.title: wefts
howtodevelop/reference/drawdown/wefts.description: Gets the number of wefts in a drawdown

howtodevelop/reference/loom/loom.title: Loom
howtodevelop/reference/loom/loom.description: A loom simply holds information about the threading, tieup and treadling that can be used to generate a particular drawdown. threading is an array the same size as there are numbers of warps. Each value in the array is a number, corresponding to the frame upon which this warp will be threaded through. The indexing for the threading begins at 0 and increases to support the total number of frames required. treadling is an array the same size as there are numbers of wefts. Each value in the array is a number, corresponding to the treadle to press. The indexing for the threading begins at 0 and increases to support the total treadles of frames required. The tieup is a 2D array of boolean values representing if the treadle in the column is tied to the row corresponding to the frame.

howtodevelop/reference/operation/dynamic.title: DynamicOperation
howtodevelop/reference/operation/dynamic.description: A dynamic operation describes a special type of operation where one of the inputs to the parameters generates inlets that accept inputs. An example is the "Image Map" function, where uploading an image file generates inlets each assigned to a different color. The dynamicparamid identifies which parameter (in the operations parameters array), triggers the generation of inlets.  dynamicparamtype describes the kind of dynamic action that will happen when this input is triggered.  onParamChange accepts a function that performs the computation to translate the dynamic parameter value into a series of inlets, returned only as value to be attached to the dynamic inlets.

howtodevelop/reference/operation/operati.title: Operation
howtodevelop/reference/operation/operati.description: Operations perform computations upon a draft. They are the core of AdaCAD, as they can be combined and arranged to "grow" different kinds of drafts. Operations each contain a set of data, which the software can interpret into an on screen element the user can add to their data flow. Each operation has a name which must be a unique name that is only used internally to locate this specific operation. old_names is a field I made when the name changes or when you no longer want to support an old operation and want to load this operation instead.

howtodevelop/reference/sequence/OneD/com.title: computeFilter
howtodevelop/reference/sequence/OneD/com.description: This function performs boolean algebra on the sequence in relationship to a second sequence. The specific boolean algebra operation is determined by an input string. To perform the algebra, it compares the values at each index of the array, and updates the sequence at that index with the resulting value. matchSize is called within this function to ensure the two sequences are always the same size.

howtodevelop/reference/sequence/OneD/imp.title: import
howtodevelop/reference/sequence/OneD/imp.description: Replaces the current state of the sequence with the values passed to the function. This function can accept an array of Cells or numbers. If cells are provided, it will store the corresponding number value associated with the cell state (see: Sequence for more information on this mapping).

howtodevelop/reference/sequence/OneD/inv.title: invert
howtodevelop/reference/sequence/OneD/inv.description: This function will invert the values of the sequence. This assumes that the numbers in the sequence correspond with 0 meaning heddle lowered and 1 meaning heddle lifted. So, this function flips 0 values to 1 and vice versa. It will leave values of 2 unchanged.

howtodevelop/reference/sequence/OneD/mat.title: matchSize
howtodevelop/reference/sequence/OneD/mat.description: This function compares the size of the current sequence to the input sequence. If they are different lengths, it will update either the input sequence or the current sequence to match the longest length by adding unset values (e.g. 2)

howtodevelop/reference/sequence/OneD/One.title: Sequence.OneD
howtodevelop/reference/sequence/OneD/One.description: A OneD Sequence object stores a single list of heddle values. You can use a OneD Sequence object to represent a single warp or weft. You can instantiate a sequence object as follows:

howtodevelop/reference/sequence/OneD/pad.title: padTo
howtodevelop/reference/sequence/OneD/pad.description: This function will add the numeric value representing the unset heddle (e.g. 2), to a sequence to make it a specified size. If the sequence is larger than the size specified, it will do nothing.

howtodevelop/reference/sequence/OneD/pus.title: push
howtodevelop/reference/sequence/OneD/pus.description: Pushes the value in passed to the function to the back of the current sequence.

howtodevelop/reference/sequence/OneD/pus.title: pushMultiple
howtodevelop/reference/sequence/OneD/pus.description: Pushes one value, multiple times, to the back of the current sequence.

howtodevelop/reference/sequence/OneD/res.title: resize
howtodevelop/reference/sequence/OneD/res.description: repeats or cuts the current sequence so that it is of a specified length.

howtodevelop/reference/sequence/OneD/uns.title: unshift
howtodevelop/reference/sequence/OneD/uns.description: Unshift pushes the value in passed to the function to the front of the current sequence.

howtodevelop/reference/sequence/OneD/uns.title: unshiftMultiple
howtodevelop/reference/sequence/OneD/uns.description: Pushes the value passed to the function to the front of the current sequence multiple times.

howtodevelop/reference/sequence/OneD/val.title: val
howtodevelop/reference/sequence/OneD/val.description: This returns a copy of the current state as an array of numbers

howtodevelop/reference/sequence/sequence.title: Sequence
howtodevelop/reference/sequence/sequence.description: The Sequence class allows you to create a 1-dimensional or 2-dimensional object and modify its contents. We created this class to streamline the process of procedurally generating drawdowns based on a limited set of rules and manipulations. We wrote mostly because, writing "createCell()" explicitly for every cell in a drawdown becomes tedious. Sequence lets you create structural patterns in a flexible manner by chaining sequences of actions together to "grow" the specific draft you need.

howtodevelop/reference/sequence/TwoD/Two.title: Sequence.TwoD
howtodevelop/reference/sequence/TwoD/Two.description: A TwoD Sequence holds a two dimensional array, similar to that of drawdown, however, storing numbers instead of Cell objects. This offers a flexible format for building drafts. For example, OneD objects can be added to TwoD objects as either rows/wefts or columns/warps.

howtouse/examples/inlay.title: Drafting Inlay for Jacquard and Harness Looms
howtouse/examples/inlay.description: The video below was created during the Experimental Textiles course using the beta version of AdaCAD. It represents one approach to drafting supplemental weft inlays using the software.

howtouse/examples/lattice-tutorial.title: Create Lattice Structures Using Layer Notation
howtouse/examples/lattice-tutorial.description: In this tutorial, we are taking inspiration from one of Elizabeth Meiklejohn's samples from the 2023 Experimental Weaving Residency. In this sample, four layers interlock to create a lattice structure. Elizabeth wove in Elastic floats between layers to pull the ends together and puffing up the structure. The elastic also allows you to pull out the sides to collapse the structure.

howtouse/examples/picture-weaving.title: Weave Images
howtouse/examples/picture-weaving.description: The video below shows how you can upload indexed color images and map drafts to the color regions. We can't yet process full color images, but if you have an indexed color image, with less than 100 colors, it should work!

howtouse/examples/quick-tc2.title: Make A Draft for the TC2
howtouse/examples/quick-tc2.description: AdaCAD an be a bit strange for those used to Photoshop and the Woven Pixel because instead of making a blank canvas and filling it with our structures, you start from the structures and "grow" them into the size of the canvas/loom that you are working with. In this tutorial, we do this by using the twill, rectangle and selvedge functions. After designing out draft, we'll export it as a bitmap image and reformat it so that it works with the TC2's interface.

howtouse/getting-started.title: Getting Started
howtouse/getting-started.description: Welcome to AdaCAD. The resources on this page will give you an overview of the interface and a few tips on how to get started drafting.

howtouse/glossary/bitmap-image.title: Bitmap Image
howtouse/glossary/bitmap-image.description: A bitmap image is a image format whereby each pixel is one of two values: black or white.

howtouse/glossary/cloth.title: Cloth
howtouse/glossary/cloth.description: The product of weaving as well as other textile processes such as knitting or crochet.

howtouse/glossary/direct-tie-loom.title: Direct Tie Loom / Dobby
howtouse/glossary/direct-tie-loom.description: A horizontal loom where each warp is threaded through a heddle, and each heddle belongs to one of a given set of frames. When a frame is raised, so too are the heddles and warps within those frames.

howtouse/glossary/draft.title: Draft
howtouse/glossary/draft.description: A draft is an abstract representation of a cloth. For example, the two images below show the correspondence between a simulated cloth and the draft that would be used to create the cloth.

howtouse/glossary/drawdown.title: Drawdown
howtouse/glossary/drawdown.description: We use the term drawdown to describe the part of the draft that represents the structure of the resulting cloth.

howtouse/glossary/end.title: End
howtouse/glossary/end.description: Refers to a single warp within the collection of warps

howtouse/glossary/glossary.title: Glossary
howtouse/glossary/glossary.description: Need help understanding what a term means? Look it up in our glossary!

howtouse/glossary/harness-loom.title: Harness Loom
howtouse/glossary/harness-loom.description: A horizontal loom where each warp is threaded through a heddle, and each heddle belongs to one of a given set of frames. When a frame is raised, so too are the heddles and warps within those frames.

howtouse/glossary/jacquard-loom.title: Jacquard Loom
howtouse/glossary/jacquard-loom.description: A horizontal loom where each warp is threaded through a heddle, and each heddle can be individually controlled, often through a computer interface.

howtouse/glossary/layer-notation.title: Layer Notation
howtouse/glossary/layer-notation.description: Layer notation emerged in conversation with Kathryn Walters, who wanted AdaCAD to help her manage complex structures that could arbitrarily map warp and weft systems to different layers, layer orders, or even different numbers of layers (e.g. a structure that goes from 2 to 4 to 3 layers for instance.) Beyond her immediate needs, we found it to be a useful system for describing the relationship between different cloth layers.

howtouse/glossary/loom.title: Loom
howtouse/glossary/loom.description: A device used to scaffold the weaving process. Looms can take various shapes and forms. They tend to share the ability to hold a set of parallel yarns (e.g. the warp) in tension between two beams.

howtouse/glossary/operation.title: Operation
howtouse/glossary/operation.description: Operations are little computational machines that take drafts as inputs, do something to them, and then spit them out as new and different, drafts. An operation consists of several parts:  inlet(s), parameters, and a resulting draft with an outlet.

howtouse/glossary/pick.title: Pick
howtouse/glossary/pick.description: Refers to a single weft insertion.

howtouse/glossary/warp.title: Warp
howtouse/glossary/warp.description: The collection of parallel yarns held in tension across the loom. Cloth is made by working weft yarns into the warp.

howtouse/glossary/warp-lowered.title: Warp Lowered
howtouse/glossary/warp-lowered.description: Another way to refer to white cells in a drawdown. We use this terminology represent locations where the warp is raised  and white cells as “warps lowered”.

howtouse/glossary/warp-raised.title: Warp Raised
howtouse/glossary/warp-raised.description: Another way to refer to black cells in a drawdown. We use this term to highlight the relationship between cells in a drawdown and actions on a loom. Specifically, it tells us that a black cell is a location where the warp end is raised. This is in contrast to white cells, which describe locations where the  “warp is lowered”.

howtouse/glossary/weft.title: Weft
howtouse/glossary/weft.description: The weft or "filling" yarn describes the yarn worked into warp. It is typically inserted perpendicularly to the warp and interlaced over and under the warp.
